name: US Laboratory Practitioner Profile
publisher: HL7 International - Orders and Observations WG

element.name: USLabPHPract
element.formal: This is the provider who either ordered a lab test or to whom the results have been sent.
element.comments: Note that a cab driver no longer fits the bill. You probably would be interested in the organization rather than the individual?.
element.requirements: Need to track doctors, staff, locums etc. for both healthcare practitioners, funders, etc.

element.formal: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.formal: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comments: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.formal: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comments: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.formal: A list of profiles that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to Profile.url.
element.comments: It is up to the server and/or other infrastruture of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over tiem.

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.formal: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comments: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.formal: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comments: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.formal: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.short: A identifier for the person as this agent
element.formal: An identifier that applies to this person in this role.
element.comments: The identifier shall be a provider NPI.
element.requirements: Either id or name is needed.

assigner.display: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS)  National Plan and Provider Enumeration System (NPPES

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. element.formal: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

binding.name: IdentifierUse
binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known

element.formal: A text string for the identifier that can be displayed to a human so they can recognize the identifier.
element.requirements: Allows humans to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

element.formal: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
element.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers.  To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular sequence or set of unique identifiers.
element.exampleUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the id itself is a full uri

element.formal: NPI Provider Number.
element.comments: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)
II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.formal: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.formal: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comments: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper
II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: A name associated with the person
element.formal: A name associated with the person.
element.requirements: Contact persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that person.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.formal: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.

binding.name: NameUse
binding.description: The use of a human name

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name
XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.formal: A full text representation of the name.
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and structured parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

element.formal: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comments: For family name, hyphenated names such as "Smith-Jones" are a single name, but names with spaces such as "Smith Jones" are broken into multiple parts.

element.short: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
element.formal: Given name.
element.comments: Can be first and middle name or initial.

element.short: Parts that come before the name
element.formal: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.

element.short: Parts that come after the name
element.formal: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.formal: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

element.short: A contact detail for the practitioner
element.formal: A contact detail for the practitioner, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
element.comments: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.
element.requirements: Need to know how to reach a practitioner.

element.formal: The postal address where the practitioner can be found or visited or to which mail can be delivered.
element.requirements: Need to keep track where the practitioner can found during work or for directing mail.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.formal: County/Parish FIPS codes.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: County/Parish Code SHALL use FIPS 6-4  ( INCITS 31:2009).

binding.description: FIPS codes for US counties and county equivalent entities

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.formal: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comments: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition should be version specific.  This will ideally be the URI for the Resource Profile defining the extension, with the code for the extension after a #.

element.formal: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.formal: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comments: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition should be version specific.  This will ideally be the URI for the Resource Profile defining the extension, with the code for the extension after a #.

element.formal: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

element.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
element.formal: The purpose of this address.
element.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

element.formal: A full text representation of the address.
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6
XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc
element.formal:
This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction, 
P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)
XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.formal: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.
Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).
element.requirements: State SHALL be the two letter USPS alphabetic codes.

element.formal: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.
ISO 3166 3 letter Country Code.
element.comments: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.
element.requirements: Country SHALL be ISO 3166 3 letter codes.

element.short: Time period when address was/is in use
element.formal: Time period when address was/is in use.
element.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

element.formal: Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
element.requirements: Needed to address the person correctly.

binding.name: AdministrativeGender
binding.description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes

element.short: The date and time of birth for the practitioner
element.formal: The date and time of birth for the practitioner.
element.requirements: Needed for identification.

element.formal: Image of the person.
element.requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of patients and personnel. Fits with newer social media usage too.

element.formal: A reference to the organization that placed the lab order.  It could be a doctor's office, hospital or clinic.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the represented organization separately, if any.

mapping.map: PRD-10 (-> 14) / PRA-9-Institution / PRT-8-Participation Organization for person participation
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)
PRD-10 (-> 14) / PRA-9-Institution / PRT-8-Participation Organization for person participation
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.short: Roles which this practitioner may perform
element.formal: Roles which this practitioner is authorized to perform for the organization.
element.comments: A person may have more than one role. At least one role is required.
element.requirements: Need to know what authority the practitioner has - what can they do?.

binding.name: PractitionerRole
binding.description: The role a person plays representing an organization

mapping.map: PRD-1 / STF-18-job title / PRA-3-practitioner category  / PRT-4-Participation / ROL-3-role-ROL / ORC-12-ordering provider / OBR-16-ordering provider / PV1-7-attending doctor / PV1-8-referring doctor / PV1-9-consulting doctor / PV1-17-admitting doctor
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

PRD-1 / STF-18-job title / PRA-3-practitioner category  / PRT-4-Participation / ROL-3-role-ROL / ORC-12-ordering provider / OBR-16-ordering provider / PV1-7-attending doctor / PV1-8-referring doctor / PV1-9-consulting doctor / PV1-17-admitting doctor
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.formal: Specific specialty of the practitioner.

binding.name: PractitionerSpecialty
binding.description: Specific specialty associated with the agency

element.short: The period during which the practitioner is authorized to perform in these role(s)
element.formal: The period during which the person is authorized to act as a practitioner in these role(s) for the organization.
element.requirements: Even after the agencies is revoked, the fact that it existed must still be recorded.

mapping.map: (ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.short: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care
element.formal: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.

element.formal: Qualifications obtained by training and certification.

element.short: An identifier for this qualification for the practitioner
element.formal: An identifier that applies to this person's qualification in this role.
element.requirements: Often, specific identities are assigned for the qualification.

element.formal: Coded representation of the qualification.

binding.name: Qualification
binding.description: Specific qualification the practitioner has to provide a service

element.short: Period during which the qualification is valid
element.formal: Period during which the qualification is valid.
element.requirements: Qualifications are often for a limited period of time, and can be revoked.

element.short: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification
element.formal: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification.

element.short: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication
element.formal: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication.
element.comments: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
element.requirements: Knowing which language a practitioner speaks can help in facilitating communication with patients.

element.name: USLabPHPract
element.formal: This is the provider who either ordered a lab test or to whom the results have been sent.

element.comments: The identifier shall be a provider NPI.
element.requirements: Either id or name is needed.

assigner.display: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS)  National Plan and Provider Enumeration System (NPPES

element.formal: NPI Provider Number.

element.comments: Can be first and middle name or initial.

element.name: USLabCounty
element.formal: County/Parish FIPS codes.
element.requirements: County/Parish Code SHALL use FIPS 6-4  ( INCITS 31:2009).

binding.name: USFIPSCounty
binding.description: FIPS codes for US counties and county equivalent entities

element.requirements: State SHALL be the two letter USPS alphabetic codes.

element.formal: US Zip Codes.
element.requirements: Zip or Postal Code SHALL be formatted as 99999[-9999] for US Zip or ZIP +4 codes.

constraint.name: Regex for Zip
constraint.human: (Zip or Postal Code) SHALL be formatted as 99999[-9999] for US Zip or ZIP +4 codes or as A9A9A9 for Canadian postal codes.

element.formal: ISO 3166 3 letter Country Code.
element.requirements: Country SHALL be ISO 3166 3 letter codes.

element.formal: A reference to the organization that placed the lab order.  It could be a doctor's office, hospital or clinic.
